awd_titl_txt: User-Centric Sensing and Distributed Control of Corridor Transportation Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This research studies the behavior and performance of a transportation corridor made of a freeway and arterial streets under a Connected Vehicles (CV) environment, where vehicles equipped with wireless communication and sensing devices collect, process, and share traffic information among themselves along with roadside sensors. First, methods of fusing/combining real-time traffic data from both vehicles and roadside sensors will be explored to automate the detection of incidents (e.g., accidents), to estimate the number of cars waiting in line and to populate the tables that contain the number of trips from origins to destinations. Second, the research studies how congestion, particularly traffic jams, emerge and spread, and how this information can help drivers cope with congestion. Finally, the research makes use of the results obtained from the first two tasks to explore algorithms that will enable the adaptive, coordinated control of freeway ramp meters and nearby arterial traffic lights, and the re-routing of traffic in response to traffic incidents.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to a better understanding of traffic congestion in corridor networks and new ways to monitor and control vehicular traffic. These can enable applications with significant societal benefits such as reduced traffic congestion and fuel consumption. The results of this research will also be disseminated to public agencies (such as Departments of Transportation (DOTs)) and the general public through presentations and brochures, and other means. This research is at the intersection of vehicular traffic flow and computer networks, it is expected to contribute to the understanding of how corridor based transportation networks work, and provides interdisciplinary training to the students involved. Minority graduate and undergraduate students will be recruited to participate in this project through college-level minority programs such as CAMP (California Alliance for Minority Participation) at the University of California Davis.

por.por_cntn:
Our research studies the behavior and performance of a transportation corridor made of a freeway and arterial streets under a Connected Vehicles (CV) environment, where vehicles equipped with wireless communication and sensing devices collect, process, and share traffic information among themselves along with roadside sensors.

Our research first developed a novel open-source integrated simulation platform called VENTOS (VEhicular NeTwork Open Simulator) to simulate vehicular traffic movements and information flows in Vehicular Ad-hoc Networks (VANETs) under different traffic management environments. Using this platform, we developed interactive routing and traffic light control algorithms to guide traffic through congested networks, taking into account the mutual influence of changes in traffic light timing and people’s switching of routes in real-time, as well as the travel time uncertainties caused by the fluctuations of traffic. We implemented and tested our routing algorithm and traffic signal control strategies in VENTOS for a downtown grid network under several traffic demand scenarios. The results show that the proposed joint routing/traffic control can reduce the overall travel time of the network significantly (in the range of 20-30%), and reduce the variance of travel speeds within the network. It was also found that, in the tested network, real-time routing is more effective when traffic is neither too light, nor too heavy, and with 20-70% of the travelers change their route in real-time.

Vehicle to Vehicle communication can enable vehicle platooning, a technique where highway traffic is organized into groups of close-following vehicles called platoon or convoy. Platooning offers many benefits, including improving traffic throughput as well as homogeneity, enhancing safety due to small speed variation, and reducing fuel consumption and emissions. We have developed a platoon management protocol based on Vehicular Ad-hoc Network (VANET) and Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC) vehicles that uses three basic platoon maneuvers: merge, split and lane-change. These three basic maneuvers can be used to accomplish various platoon operations, such as vehicle entry, platoon leader leave, and follower leave. Both the platoon management protocol and the CACC vehicle control logic are implemented in our simulator VENTOS. The software has been released in the Open Source portal GitHub and being used by researchers in the Connected and Autonomous Vehicles community.

While connectivity enables better management of traffic, it also exposes the traffic system to malicious attacks. We took a first look at the effects of security attacks on the communication channel as well as sensor tampering of a vehicle stream equipped to perform Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC). Six attack scenarios were identified and simulation of such attacks was carried out in VENTOS. The results show that significant instabilities arise in the CACC vehicle streams when attacked by a malicious adversary. Countermeasures such as Local Plausibility Check, Verification with Other In-Vehicle Devices (such as smart phones or wearables a traveler carries with her), and Voting were proposed to improve security of the (autonomous) vehicle communication and sensor systems and the safety of the drivers and passengers.

The results of this research have helped us understand better how route-switching and traffic signal control affects traffic congestion under different demand levels, and the potential of platooning in improving traffic operations. It also exposes the security risks of the connected vehicle environment and provided remedies to address such risks. As this research is at the intersection of vehicular traffic flow and computer networks, it provided interdisciplinary training to three PhD students, two Master’s students, five undergraduate students, and one minority high school student. It also contributed to technology transfer through its open source platform VENTOS.
